newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds open weaker with U.S. in quiet trade.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds open weaker with U.S. in quiet trade.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened weaker in quiet trade on Friday, amid a softer U.S. Treasuries market and strong Canadian economic data, analysts said.

"The market trades like it's going to go lower. I think it will," said Hank Cunningham, director of fixed-income with First Marathon Securities Ltd. "People are very cautious here in this market after this beating. The market was overextended for sure. We're settleing back to what should be more normal levels."
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond fell C$0.98 to C$118.61 to yield 6.568 percent.
The U.S. 30-year bond fell 26/32 to yield 6.61 percent. The negative spread between the bonds narrowed to four basis points from six basis points on Thursday's close.
Canadian bonds opened weaker with U.S. treasuries, which softened in early trade in tandem with the U.S. dollar. Cunningham said U.S. dealers were also on the defensive after recent refundings.

The only major economic news out this morning was the Canadian composite leading indicator for July, which rose 0.8 percent. A Reuters survey of economists had forecast the smoothed index to rise 0.7 percent.
"The leading indicator is very strong in Canada again. This is a hot economy," said Cunningham.

Dealers said the market was still feeling the effect of a short squeeze at the two-year portion of the curve, which became apparent on Thursday. The Government of Canada 4.0 percent bond due March 15, 1999 traded down C$0.05 to C$99.71 to yield 4.191 percent.
In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bond fell C$0.55 to C$109.02 to yield 6.015 percent.
The U.S. 10-year bond fell 11/32 to yield 6.30 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds narrowed to 29 basis points from 32 basis points at Thursday's close.
The 10-year Canadian government bond futures contract trading on the Montreal Exchange fell 0.39 to 119.75 with 1870 contracts changing hands.
